title: Orford Ness Walking Route

images.title: Phil Champion / Random rusting remains, Orford Ness, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Random rusting remains.  Orford Ness is littered with the decaying remnants of over half a century of military occupation. This is near the Bomb Ballistics building. The buildings in the background are the atomic weapons test cells at the Atomic Weapons Research Establishment (AWRE) site.

images.title: Phil Champion / 'The Barracks', Orford Ness, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: 'The Barracks'. This building dates from 1945 and was originally used by the Photo Section to process film from cameras which recorded weapons trials on Orford Ness. Today it is used as an accommodation block for National Trust volunteers and researchers working on the site.

images.title: Andy Parrett / Plant life on Orford Ness, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Plant life on Orford Ness Summer flowering plants growing in shingle near to the Black Beacon (out of shot to the left)

images.title: Alison Rawson / Shingle bank on Orford Ness, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Shingle bank on Orford Ness Part of the 16 kilometre long shingle spit.

images.title: Phil Champion / The Black Beacon, Orford Ness, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Black Beacon, Orford Ness. The building on the right was built to house an experimental navigation beacon. The building on the left housed the power units for the beacon.

images.title: Andy Parrett / Plant on Orford Ness, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Plant on Orford Ness. Small flowering plant very near the Spring Tide mark. Visitors are encouraged to walk as near to the sea as possible to avoid disturbing the shingle as this is a very vulnerable habitat.

images.title: Andy Parrett / Orford Ness footpaths, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Orford Ness footpaths. These walkers are on the 'red route', and just where the wooden fences are, to the right of the picture, is a turning for the 'blue route' which goes across the old airfield area.

images.title: Alison Rawson / Lighthouse at Orford Ness, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lighthouse at Orford Ness

description: Follow the walking trails around this beautiful nature reserve on the Suffolk Coast. The reserve is located on a remote shingle spit by the River Ore. It can be accessed by catching the National Trust ferry from Orford Quay (this is show on the google street view link below). You can then pick up the walking trails which take you to the WWI airfield, King's Marsh, Orford Ness lighthouse and Orford beach. There's three colour coded, waymarked trails to try with reserve features including shingle, salt-marsh, mud-flats and brackish lagoons. These areas are a haven for wildlife. Highlights include Orford's brown hares and the wonderful Chinese water deer who swam the river to reach the reserve.  Also look out for a wide variety of birds such as avocet and common tern. Marsh harrier's have a nest in King's Marsh and Barn Owls can also been seen nesting in the disused military buildings on the site. To extend your walking in the area you could pick up the waterside footpath along the River Ore and River Alde and head north towards Aldeburgh Bay. The Suffolk Coast Path also runs near to the reserve. You can pick it up a couple of miles west of Orford where it runs along the Butley River to Boyton Marshes. Just to the north of the reserve you will find the village of Snape and the interesting Snape Maltings.  The area also includes an expansive arts complex on the banks of the River Alde. Rendlesham Forest is also nearby and has miles of nice woodland walking trails.
